title-group.article-title: Early time‐restricted feeding improves high‐density lipoprotein amount and function in nonhuman primates, without effects on body composition
title-group.alt-title: EARLY TIME‐RESTRICTED FEEDING IMPROVES HDL FUNCTION

aff.institution: Wake Forest University School of Medicine

aff.named-content: Department of Internal Medicine‐Section on Molecular Medicine
aff.institution: Wake Forest University School of Medicine
Wake Forest University School of Medicine

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence Kylie Kavanagh, Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Medical Center Boulevard, Winston‐Salem, NC 27157, USA. Email: kkavanag@wakehealth.edu

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: Time‐restricted feeding (TRF), whereby caloric intake is limited to a <12‐hour window, is a potential regimen to ameliorate metabolic syndrome and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk co‐occurring with aging and with obesity. Early TRF (eTRF; early morning feeding followed by overnight fasting) times calorie consumption with hepatic circadian gene expression rhythms. Brief TRF trials demonstrate that high‐density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol increases similar to diet/exercise interventions, which may impart beneficial CVD effects. Using a nonhuman primate (NHP) model, the efficacy of eTRF to raise HDL and increase plasma cholesterol efflux capacity (CEC) (primarily mediated by cholesterol efflux to HDL particles, a process that is inversely associated with CVD risk) was examined.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Adult (8–16 years old, n = 25) and geriatric (≥17 years old) NHPs were randomized to ad libitum feeding or eTRF for 12 months, and relevant body composition, glycemic control, and plasma HDL cholesterol levels and CEC were measured.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Impaired CEC was found in geriatric NHPs. eTRF induced larger‐sized HDL particles, increased HDL apolipoprotein A‐1 content, lowered triglyceride concentrations, and increased plasma CEC (primarily to HDL particles) in both adult and geriatric NHPs without changes in glycemic control or body composition.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A beneficial effect of eTRF on increasing HDL CEC in NHPs was demonstrated.

institution-wrap.institution: National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences
National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute

p.mixed-citation: KavanaghK, BashoreAC, DavisMA, et al. Early time‐restricted feeding improves high‐density lipoprotein amount and function in nonhuman primates, without effects on body composition. Obesity (Silver Spring). 2023;31(Suppl. 1):75‐84. doi:10.1002/oby.23564 36229981

fn.p: Funding information National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences, Grant/Award Number: UL1TR001420; National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute, Grant/Award Number: R01HL119962; NIH Office of the Director, Grant/Award Number: P40OD010965

list-item.p: Time‐restricted feeding (TRF) has been effective in improving both body composition and cardiovascular risk factors in animal models and people.
Early time‐restricted feeding (eTRF) is a refinement of the strategy to match the circadian rhythmic gene expression patterns observed in tissues such as the liver.

Geriatric nonhuman primate (NHP) plasma has deficient cholesterol efflux capacity, and long‐term exposure to eTRF in NHPs improves cholesterol efflux capacity in both adult and geriatric NHP populations.
High‐density lipoprotein particles become larger and more apolipoprotein A‐1 rich with eTRF.
Triglyceride levels improve with eTRF, and lipid and lipoprotein changes are seen without changes in body composition.

sec.title: How might these results change the direction of research or the focus of clinical practice?

list-item.p: eTRF may be a strategy for the improvement of cardiovascular risk in adult and elderly populations.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The developed world is rapidly aging and obesity prevalence is increasing, with the leading all‐cause mortality being attributed to cardiovascular disease (CVD) [1]. These risk factors, age and obesity, often lead to metabolic syndrome and high rates of polypharmacy [2]. Nonpharmaceutical approaches, such as diet and exercise, are universally effective, readily recommended by physicians, and generally well accepted by patients. However, these interventions are often difficult to adhere to, because people may be limited by access to affordable healthy food, may lack time and knowledge about food preparation, and may have individual preferences. Exercise also can be limited by factors that include reduced mobility, which often co‐occurs with advanced age and obesity, as well as access to spaces and adequate time to recreate [3]. For these reasons, time‐restricted feeding (TRF) has gained attention as a strategy that does not rely on diet change or exercise but that has beneficial effects on weight and CVD risk factors [4]. TRF is the concept whereby the type and amount of calories consumed are not the focus of change, but calorie consumption is limited to a less than 12‐hour window, establishing a regular periodic fasting period. TRF has shown promising effects in early clinical trials for risk factors associated with cardiometabolic diseases [5, 6, 7, 8]. A subtle modification of TRF has been proposed based on observations of gene expression patterns having circadian rhythms [6, 9]. Genes showing daily expression patterns include those expressed in liver that peak during the early morning hours [9]. Early TRF (eTRF) prescribes the feeding period to begin in early morning and fasting to occur overnight to match decreased circadian gene expression.

Circulatory cholesterol distribution among the lipoprotein particles is a key CVD risk biomarker. Short‐term clinical trials employing a range of TRF windows, from every other day TRF to consistent 12‐hour feeding windows, have shown that high‐density lipoprotein (HDL)‐associated cholesterol (HDL‐C) increases in younger, healthier populations in a manner similar to that seen with the implementation of recommended dietary and exercise paradigms [4]. Improved circulatory lipid profiles, characterized by reduced low‐density lipoprotein–associated cholesterol and increased HDL‐C, lead to a reduction in CVD risk via HDL‐C–mediated reverse cholesterol transport [10, 11]. HDL‐C particles convey both cardioprotective and anti‐inflammatory effects, particularly relevant to populations with overweight and geriatric populations, who commonly have higher circulating levels of inflammatory cytokines thought to impair function in multiple body systems. In recent decades, raising HDL‐C has been a prime target for pharmaceutical development, yet strategies to increase reverse cholesterol transport by HDL‐C have been largely unsuccessful [10, 11, 12, 13].

A gap in knowledge exists regarding how the positive effects of TRF on metabolic syndrome risk separate from efficacy in inducing weight loss and caloric restriction (CR). These contributions have been difficult to disentangle, as weight loss is commonly observed in TRF/CR studies [4, 14]. In the current study, we employed a nonhuman primate (NHP) model with a long history of use in lipoprotein and CVD research to evaluate eTRF effects on HDL‐C [15, 16]. We investigated whether chronic eTRF positively affected plasma HDL and cholesterol efflux capacity (CEC) using a highly controlled study environment with both adult and geriatric NHPs.

sec.title: Study animals
sec.p: All procedures were performed in accordance with the Guide for Care and Use of Laboratory Animals. Protocols for avoidance of pain and discomfort were adhered to and conducted in compliance with the Wake Forest University School of Medicine Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee. The Wake Forest School of Medicine is accredited by the Association for Assessment and Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care International and it operates in compliance with the Animal Welfare Act.

This study included both adult (≥7–16 years old) and geriatric (≥17 years old) African green monkeys (Chlorocebus aethiops sabaeus), maintained as part of the Wake Forest University Vervet Research Colony. The Vervet Research Colony is a multigenerational breeding NHP colony that we have studied extensively, and its metabolic health and health diversity have been previously published [16, 17].

All study subjects consumed commercially prepared diets. For comparison of age‐related differences in CEC, we assessed adult and geriatric monkeys while they consumed a low‐fat, low‐cholesterol, and low‐simple‐carbohydrate laboratory chow (LabDiet 5038). To assess diet‐related effects on HDL and the effects of eTRF, the monkeys were then fed a Western diet (LabDiet 5L3K), which included moderate cholesterol content (600 ppm, 3.66 kcal/g), 19.4% protein, 33.9% fat, and 46.7% carbohydrates. Simple carbohydrates composed 19% of total calories. The details of each diet are tabulated in Supporting Information Table S1.

Following baseline assessments, adult and geriatric animals were further stratified to one of two experimental groups, receiving either ad libitum feeding (24‐hour diet access) or eTRF, wherein subjects had access to the diet only from approximately 6 AM until 2 PM daily. This 8‐hour feeding regimen is based on positive outcomes reported in small, short‐term human clinical trials [6, 7, 18, 19] and the hypothesis that these feeding hours better align with increased circadian gene expression patterns known to exist in humans and NHPs [6, 9, 20]. Diet consumption continued for a total of 12 months, with measurements performed at regular time points as illustrated in Figure 1. The numbers in each treatment group varied, as is the case in most clinically oriented studies, based on animal availability at each time point, with group sizes indicated in table and figure legends.

caption.p: Overall study schema in which adult nonhuman primates (NHPs; n = 25) and geriatric NHPs (n = 21) were fed a high‐fat, ‐sugar, and ‐cholesterol diet modeled on current Westernized countries' consumption patterns. NHPs were divided evenly into ad libitum access to food or access only between 6 a.m. and 2 p.m. in an early time‐restricted feeding (eTRF) paradigm. Cardiometabolic outcomes, including plasma cholesterol efflux capacity, were measured at selected time points during the yearlong study. A1c, glycosylation of hemoglobin chain (a biomarker of glycemic control). HDL, high‐density lipoprotein

sec.p: For all of the following experimental procedures, animals were fasted overnight prior to being sedated via intramuscular injection of ketamine (10 mg/kg) and midazolam (0.1 mg/kg). Blood sampling for all measurements was conducted via percutaneous femoral venipuncture.

sec.title: Quantification of plasma CEC and radiolabeled cholesterol distribution among plasma lipoproteins
sec.p: CEC was measured in adult and geriatric animals on a low‐fat, low‐cholesterol diet to assess differences related to chronological age and also after 8 months of eTRF or ad libitum consumption of the Western diet. CEC efflux was quantified as described previously [21], with minor modifications. J774 macrophages were plated in 24 multiwell plates (150,000 cells/well for 24 hours) and radiolabeled with 1‐μCi/mL 3H‐cholesterol (Perkin Elmer; NET139001MC) for an additional 24 hours. Phospholipid‐transporting ATPase ABCA1 was upregulated by a 20‐hour incubation with 0.3mM 8‐bromoadenosine 3′,5′‐cyclic monophosphate (8‐Br‐cAMP; Sigma; B5386). Subsequently, efflux medium containing 2% plasma was added for 4 hours. Each sample was run in triplicate, and a pooled plasma standard was used to correct for interassay variation. To correct for background efflux, plasma‐free wells were also included. Following the efflux period, medium was collected and cellular lipids were harvested by incubating cells overnight with hexane:isoproponal (3:2). Percentage efflux was calculated using the following formula: [(μCi of 3H‐cholesterol in medium containing 2% plasma) ÷ (μCi of 3H‐cholesterol in cell extract + μCi of 3H‐cholesterol in medium)]. To calculate specific efflux, background efflux to plasma‐free wells was subtracted. To correct for interassay variation across plates, samples were normalized to the pooled plasma control.

To analyze distribution of 3H‐radiolabel across lipoprotein species at completion of efflux procedure, 200 μL of pooled media (equal volume from each animal) from each group was applied to a Superose 6 Increase 10/300 GL gel filtration column (GE Healthcare; 29‐0915‐96). The samples were eluted at a flow rate of 0.4 mL/min in a Tris buffer (10mM Tris, 0.15M NaCl, 1mM EDTA, 0.2% NaN3), and eluate was collected in 1‐minute fractions and radiolabel in each fraction quantified with liquid scintillation spectroscopy.

sec.title: Plasma measurements
sec.p: Lipid parameters assayed included total plasma cholesterol (TPC), HDL‐C, and triglycerides (TG). TPC was measured by enzymatic techniques based on the methods of Allain et al. [22]. HDL‐C concentrations were measured using a slight modification (2M MnCl2) of the heparin‐manganese precipitation procedure described in the Manual of Laboratory Operations of the Lipid Research Clinics Program. All lipid analyses were performed on an ACE Alera Clinical Chemistry System (Alfa Wasserman, Inc.) at Wake Forest University Health Sciences, which subscribes to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention–National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Lipids Standardization Program.

For subsequent lipoprotein measurements, an aliquot of plasma containing ~20 μg of TPC was diluted in phosphate‐buffered saline (PBS) into a volume of 400 μL. After centrifugation to remove any protein precipitates, samples were injected onto a Superose 6 HR 10/30 (Amersham Pharmacia) chromatography column run at 0.4 mL/min. Lipoprotein cholesterol was determined by multiplying the TPC concentration by the cholesterol percentage within the elution region for each lipoprotein class. The elution was mixed with cholesterol reagent that created a colorimetric signal, which was integrated using Chrom Perfect Spirit Software (Justice Laboratory Software). HDL size estimations were measured by peak retention time on the elution chromatograph for each individual. Measures were performed at baseline, 2 months, and 12 months in the eTRF interventional study. The 5‐minute eluted fractions between 30 and 45 minutes containing HDL were collected in four randomly selected animals per group for subsequent analysis of apolipoproteins. Levels of lipoprotein‐associated apolipoprotein A‐1 (ApoA‐1), ApoA‐4, and ApoE proteins and the enzymes cholesterol ester transfer protein and lecithin–cholesterol acyltransferase were measured by electrophoretic separation and immunodetection after transfer to nitrocellulose membranes, as previously described [23]. These measures were performed at the end of the eTRF study. The antibodies used are provided in Supporting Information Table S2.

Glycemic control was measured by fasting plasma glucose concentrations using the glucose oxidase method, and glycosylated hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) percentage values were measured in whole blood using a point‐of‐care diagnostic assay (Afinion Alere; Abbott). Glycemic control was measured at baseline and at study end to assess effects of eTRF.

sec.title: Body composition
sec.p: Dual‐energy X‐ray absorptiometry (Hologic Discovery A Dual X‐ray Bone Densitometer) scans were performed to quantitate overall body fat content at baseline and after 8 months of diet consumption. Body weight measures were also recorded and similarly tracked at all data time points.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: All data were tested for normality prior to statistical assessments and transformed when necessary to allow parametric testing. A two‐factor ANOVA model (diet and age group) was applied to find differences in HDL‐related parameters prior to study and at baseline, 2 months, and study end. Body weight, body fat, HbA1c, and TG values were measured repeatedly at different time points over 12 months of study and were evaluated by linear regression models that control for initial value and group assignment. Test subject baseline value for each assessed variable was generally significant in predicting outcome. In all analyses, p ≤ 0.05 was considered significant. Results are reported as the statistical probability associated with each effect present in the model: diet group, age group, time, or diet × age interaction where applicable. Data are presented as means, with standard error of the mean, and the number of individuals available to sample at each assessment is indicated. The study involved applying eTRF or ad libitum feeding to an active breeding and resource colony, such that individuals may have missing data due to pregnancy, death, sale, or other experimental protocols.

sec.title: Age decreases HDL function
sec.p: Prior to initiation of the eTRF study, we evaluated cholesterol efflux in the selected cohort of NHPs eating a typical laboratory low‐fat, ‐sugar, and ‐cholesterol chow diet. All animals had comparable housing environments and supplemental fruit and vegetables. In this cohort of NHPs, plasma CEC of geriatric monkeys (n = 21, mean age 21.1 ± 0.65 years; p < 0.001) was 9% lower than adult NHPs (n = 25, mean age 11.7 ± 0.46 years; p = 0.03, Figure 2).

caption.p: Geriatric nonhuman primates (NHPs; n = 21) have impaired plasma cholesterol efflux as compared with adult NHPs (n = 25). A 9% reduction was observed (*p = 0.03). Normalized mean efflux values (±SEM) are shown. Normalized results corrected for a pooled plasma control sample. Uncorrected mean values were 14.5% vs. 13.4% efflux in adult and geriatric samples, respectively (p < 0.05). AU, arbitrary units

sec.title: eTRF improves HDL function in geriatric and adult monkeys
sec.p: Plasma from NHPs with eTRF of a Western diet for 8 months had increased CEC (p = 0.01) compared with ad libitum–fed animals, regardless of age, as illustrated in Figure 3A. Our sample sizes were smaller than comparisons shown in Figure 1, so a statistically significant interaction between age group and intervention effect was not detected (p = 0.74). These data suggest that eTRF is equally, if not more, effective in the geriatric NHP population. To determine which lipoprotein fractions were responsible for the improved CEC in plasma from eTRF animals, efflux media was size fractionated by fast protein liquid chromatography (FPLC), and radiolabeled cholesterol distributions among plasma lipoprotein fractions were quantified (Figure 3B). More radiolabeled cholesterol was found in HDL fractions (elution time near 40 minutes) from adult and geriatric monkeys in the eTRF group compared with their respective ad libitum–fed counterparts.

caption.p: (A) Early time‐restricted feeding (eTRF) restores plasma efflux capacity in both adult and geriatric nonhuman primates (NHPs). The positive effect of eTRF was significant (**p = 0.01) and equivalent in geriatric NHPs as compared with younger adults (diet × age p = 0.74). Sample sizes appear as integers shown on the data columns. Normalized mean efflux values (±SEM) are shown. Unadjusted values showed adults improving from 13.2% to 14.8% and geriatrics from 12.4% to 14.5% with eTRF (p < 0.05). (B) Media from efflux experiments were chromatographically separated to show higher counts in eTRF groups in the ≈40‐minute range, which corresponds to the high‐density lipoprotein (HDL) fractions. Lower counts are present in the earlier peaks corresponding to very low‐density lipoprotein (VLDL) and low‐density lipoprotein (LDL) particles. Pooled media for each group were evaluated, with each animal equally represented in the sample. AU, arbitrary units.

sec.title: eTRF is associated with more and larger HDL particles enriched with ApoA‐1
sec.p: Size chromatographic results clearly demonstrate that eTRF treatment led to larger and more cholesterol‐rich HDL‐C particles, as indicated by significantly (p = 0.03) shorter column retention times regardless of subject age (Figure 4A,B). Larger HDL particles had more ApoA‐1 associated with them (p = 0.01 for the effect of eTRF); ApoA‐1 results (Figure 4A,B) were also substantiated by HDL‐C and TPC measures in plasma (Table 1). TPC increased in all animals over the course of study (p = 0.03), consistent with moving from low‐cholesterol to high‐cholesterol dietary exposure. Group differences were not significant; however, the increases in TPC in both ad libitum and eTRF groups were numerically greater in geriatric animals over the course of study (ad libitum adults increased 7% and geriatric increased 12%, whereas eTRF adults increased 8% and geriatric increased 14%). HDL‐C also increased in all groups over the study (p = 0.007). We believe the increase in total cholesterol mostly moved to the HDL fraction, making them larger. eTRF adult monkeys had 36% higher ApoA‐1 and eTRF geriatric monkeys had 46% higher ApoA‐1 levels in their plasma HDL fraction (p = 0.01 for both; Figure 4A,B). We also measured ApoA‐4 and ApoE, which may affect HDL function, and no differences were observed by age or diet grouping (Table 2).

caption.p: A high‐density lipoprotein (HDL) particle size was estimated based on chromatographic retention times. Average chromatograms are shown. Adult retention times for HDL were 39.1 minutes with ad libitum feeding and 38 minutes with early time‐restricted feeding (eTRF). Geriatric HDL retention times were 38.6 minutes with ad libitum feeding and 38 minutes with eTRF (p = 0.03 for the overall effect of eTRF). (B) Larger HDL particles had more associated ApoA‐1 (**p = 0.01 for the effect of eTRF). Adult nonhuman primates (NHPs) maintained on eTRF had 36% higher ApoA‐1 and geriatric NHPs had 46% higher ApoA‐1 levels in their plasma HDL fractions. Group sizes evaluated were four per age and diet group. LDL, low‐density lipoprotein; VLDL, very low‐density lipoprotein
Plasma lipid measures, including TPC, HDL‐C, and TG, at baseline and after 12 months on study

fn.p: Note: Values displayed are mean ± SEM (n = 7–9/group). A significant effect of time was present with all groups showing an increase in TPC (p = 0.03) as a result of exposure to a cholesterol‐containing diet. Interactions with age and diet group were nonsignificant.
Abbreviations: eTRF, early time‐restricted feeding; HDL‐C, high‐density lipoprotein cholesterol; TG, triglycerides; TPC, total plasma cholesterol.
p < 0.05, overall effect of eTRF lowering TG vs. ad libitum feeding.

caption.p: Lipoprotein measurements, including ApoA‐4, CETP, and LCAT, in a randomly selected subset of animals (n = 4 per group) after 8 months on study

tr.td: p value for ad libitum vs. eTRF

fn.p: Note: Values displayed are mean ± SEM; units are AU/μg plasma protein × 108.
Abbreviations: CETP, cholesterol ester transfer protein; eTRF, early time‐restricted feeding; LCAT, lecithin–cholesterol acyltransferase.

sec.title: TG profiles improved with eTRF in the absence of changes in adiposity or glycemic control
sec.p: Controlled for baseline values, eTRF significantly reduced plasma TG concentrations (Table 1; p = 0.014), with an overall reduction of 12.1 mg/dL with eTRF when variables of age, body weight, and time were controlled for, and no difference in adult versus geriatric groups was present. The duration of study also did not change the magnitude of the effect of eTRF (p = 0.91). All improvements in TG and HDL were independent of changes in adiposity or improvements in glycemic control (Table 3). This is an important distinguishing feature of this monkey study; human clinical trials are commonly confounded by improvement in body composition in the control or comparison groups [19]. HbA1c showed that no significant time × group interaction was noted after 12 months (Table 3; p = 0.10). One geriatric animal in the eTRF group became diabetic, which is reflected in the average and variability estimates of HbA1c in this group at 12 months. Body weight and composition are presented in Table 3, with comparable differences that remained consistent across time observed between the groups (group × time p = 0.87; Supporting Information Table S4). Dual‐energy X‐ray absorptiometry scans (Supporting Information Table S5) performed at baseline and after 8 months demonstrated that lean mass remained unchanged over time (p = 0.91), and both groups lost comparable, but not statistically significant, amounts of body fat (p = 0.65). Data for adjusted HbA1c levels by diet condition across time are presented in Supporting Information Table S6.

caption.p: Metabolic and glycemic indices, including body weight, percentage body fat (via DXA scan), plasma glucose, and HbA1c

fn.p: Note: Sample size range was 7–12 individuals per diet condition for each age grouping.
Abbreviations: DXA, dual‐energy X‐ray absorptiometry; eTRF, early time‐restricted feeding; HbA1c, hemoglobin A1c.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: To our knowledge, this study is the only preclinical eTRF intervention to date, with numerous notable findings in a highly clinically relevant NHP model. We found that eTRF markedly improved NHP plasma lipid concentrations and HDL‐C composition and function, independent of changes in body weight or fat composition. Moreover, these ameliorations were equivalently robust in both adult and geriatric cohorts. As such, eTRF could be a specific recommendation for geriatric populations with, or at risk of, CVD. Furthermore, we found no associations between plasma CEC and body composition changes, further suggesting that eTRF may be effective in populations with overweight/obesity independent of weight loss.

Changes reported in HDL‐C with eTRF are generally absent or exhibit very small increases, but clinical conclusions are hampered by the small number of quality trials and the short‐term nature of those that have been published [8, 19, 24]. The small HDL‐C benefits observed in other human studies mostly fail to be statistically significant and co‐occur with meaningful changes in body weight [5, 6, 7, 25, 26]. Weight loss typically results in the intervention arms of most TRF human studies [4, 19, 26], which can confound the interpretation of lipid changes. In the current study, we did not see increases in circulatory HDL‐C, nor improvements in body weight or glycemic measures, which is consistent with many clinical studies. It is worth noting that a significant reduction in TG was achieved with eTRF in NHPs, and this has also been a repeatable outcome in human clinical trials [19, 27]. As significant and sustained weight loss is rarely achieved and the current obesity epidemic continues unabated [28], finding strategies that can improve health in the absence of weight loss is important.

Our data demonstrate improved HDL function regardless of HDL‐C concentrations in circulation. However, this disconnect is consistent with reports that HDL levels only explain about 33% of the variance measured in cholesterol efflux assays [29]. Furthermore, in a large cohort study, HDL‐C concentration did not predict adverse cardiovascular incidence over a period of over 9 years [11]. In this analysis, Rohatgi et al. offer proof that HDL CEC is a key functional property of the HDL lipoprotein particle, independent of HDL‐C levels, and is able to predict cardiovascular events. This finding was an important advancement of knowledge gained from prior cross‐sectional studies that also supported the protective role of higher efflux measures [10]. These data indicated a 25% difference in risk for CVD events per standard deviation of CEC, which translates in our data set to a predicted 12.5% reduction in CVD risk in primates adhering to eTRF for 6 months. The benefit may be greater in older subjects who demonstrated poor plasma CEC at baseline but had larger improvements with eTRF and were comparable to younger adults by the end of the intervention. Reductions in CEC with aging might be secondary to the low‐grade inflammation commonly observed in older people and primates [30, 31], with inflammation decreasing the preβ‐1 subpopulation of the HDL particle type, which has the greatest capacity for cholesterol acceptance [32]. This mechanism may also be relevant to the low‐grade inflammation present with unhealthy obesity [33]. Concordant with this is the sustained improvement in HDL CEC observed in patients with obesity subjected to bariatric surgical procedures, but not in the lifestyle‐counseled control group that also had significantly less change in their inflammatory biomarkers [34].

HDL‐C values do not provide information about the ApoA‐1 containing particle subclasses in circulation. Our study points to a clear shift toward larger HDL particle size, which can result from more TG content, and TG is known to interfere with CEC function [35]. Because total TG in circulation decreased and CEC improved, the larger size is less likely to reflect TG contained within HDL particles. Larger particles can be highly functional depending on their protein, lipid, phospholipid, and micro‐RNA cargo composition. In women transitioning across menopause, CVD disease rates increase substantially, concomitant with loss of larger HDL particles [36]. In these menopausal women, HDL CEC reductions associate with loss of ApoA‐1 levels, highlighting this protein as a key HDL particle feature that confers CVD protection [36]. Herein, we show that eTRF boosted ApoA‐1 concentrations substantially, with a moderate blunting in that increase with aging. Of the protein components measured, ApoA‐1 alone was altered with eTRF. ApoA‐1 composes more than two thirds of the HDL particle protein mass and is the primary protein acquiring cholesterol from membranes in reverse cholesterol transport. Increasing ApoA‐1 is an important outcome because this protein has multiple antioxidant functions in addition to facilitation of cholesterol transport [13].

The timing of intervention is a relevant feature of the eTRF paradigm. Shifting the feeding window to the early morning hours parallels the highest endogenous cortisol levels and increases in a suite of circadian clock genes [6]. Consistent with eTRF supporting the expression of endogenous diurnal rhythms is that mice with genetic mutations that impair circadian clock gene expression have significant metabolic health improvements with TRF, including circulating cholesterol and TG levels. This suggests that a TRF pattern can induce rhythmic gene expression related to feeding and fasting that is consistent with the mammalian circadian clock [37]. In TRF clinical trials, small nonsignificant changes in HDL‐C have been observed, but in one trial, small improvements were observed in the morning but they were no longer present when measures were repeated in the evening [6, 8, 24]. In a larger clinical trial comparing feeding windows of early and midday, eTRF was superior in CR, improving body composition and (relevant to our results) the liver marker aspartate transaminase [8]. The repeated fasting and refeeding that occurs in eTRF protocols induces specific gene expression changes in the liver that regulate lipogenesis and cholesterol synthesis. Furthermore, the liver is the major site for ApoA‐1 protein production. Key transcriptional factors modifying lipid and cholesterol metabolism include carbohydrate‐responsive element‐binding protein, liver X receptors (LXR), and sterol regulatory element‐binding protein 1, which are downregulated in the fasted state because of low exposure to glucose and insulin in the portal circulation [38]. Fasting and CR also reduce cytosolic stress in hepatocytes and peripheral blood mononuclear cells, with the protection of chaperone proteins required for proteostasis, protein translation, and autophagy [25, 39]. Improved hepatic production of proteins, such as the apolipoproteins, is supported by proteomic analyses of fasting human plasma, in which ApoA‐2, ApoA‐4, and ApoC‐3 were identified as upregulated proteins [40]. Hepatic ApoA‐4 gene transcription is also a key target in fasting–refeeding studies of rodent liver [20]. In alternative day fasting, which is different than eTRF, the peripheral blood mononuclear cell proteome identified lipoprotein metabolism and lipid transporter activity as upregulated pathways, despite no significant change in plasma HDL‐C [25]. We did not observe changes in ApoA‐4, but a more comprehensive proteomics analysis may have detected these and other changes.

Our study has some limitations. Additional information about the eTRF‐mediated shift in HDL particle composition by proteomic and lipidomic profiling is not available. Furthermore, we relied on a single measure of particle size. Although our study is long for a NHP preclinical trial, it is not long enough to observe definitive CVD outcomes such as atheroma formation. Food intake and activity levels of the individual NHPs were not measured because of the social housing and group feeding environment. As body composition parameters remained consistent throughout study, diet consumption patterns likely shifted to accommodate feeding schedule, which is a phenomenon observed in other time‐restricted fed animals [41]. Finally, we measured plasma CEC rather than HDL CEC as in other studies. Regardless, we observed that the majority of CEC was localized to HDL particles, suggesting that plasma CEC in our study primarily reflects cellular cholesterol efflux to HDL.

In conclusion, plasma CEC improved significantly with eTRF, regardless of age, in our translationally relevant NHP model. This improvement was seen in concert with increased ApoA‐1, larger HDL particle size, and reduced plasma TG levels. Notably, these beneficial changes in CVD risk biomarkers occurred without changes in body composition. Our study has unique strengths in that it employed a relevant Western diet, containing high fat, simple sugars, and cholesterol in both the eTRF and ad libitum–fed monkeys, and it was of sufficient duration to assess stable and persistent metabolic changes. Our data point to functional HDL improvements with larger HDL particles that contain greater ApoA‐1, and this is the first study of eTRF, to our knowledge, to demonstrate such changes in a preclinical trial of this size and duration. These data add to the growing body of evidence that eTRF is a good strategy, with or without CR, to improve health.

sec.title: FUNDING INFORMATION
sec.p: This study was funded by NIH P40OD010965, UL1TR001420, and R01HL119962 (to JSP).

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST
sec.p: The authors declared no conflict of interest.
